messages.message:
Hello Turkey, nice to make your acquaintance. 

I've been thinking about this game alot, because the fact that it will only last until 1910 really changes my strategy. Add in that no one is likely to NMR and I believe it will be near impossible to solo. As such, it really only makes sense to find a ride or die partner for close tactical coordination and grab as many centers as possible.

As I'm sure you know, when R/T can trust each other and are firing on all 8 the Juggernaut can be nearly unstoppable. You, as Turkey, are my number 1 preferred partner in this game. I propose that we ally to dominate the Eastern sphere of this game. Do you agree?
messages.input:
Message from RUSSIA:'Hello Turkey, nice to make your acquaintance. 

I've been thinking about this game alot, because the fact that it will only last until 1910 really changes my strategy. Add in that no one is likely to NMR and I believe it will be near impossible to solo. As such, it really only makes sense to find a ride or die partner for close tactical coordination and grab as many centers as possible.

As I'm sure you know, when R/T can trust each other and are firing on all 8 the Juggernaut can be nearly unstoppable. You, as Turkey, are my number 1 preferred partner in this game. I propose that we ally to dominate the Eastern sphere of this game. Do you agree?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's proposal to ally and pursue dominance in the Eastern sphere with Turkey aligns with common strategic interests and the potential for strong cooperation. This message indicates a genuine interest in collaboration and setting a solid groundwork for a successful alliance in the game.

messages.message:
I mean, who doesn't like a good Juggernaut?  Always a fun start to the game!  

How do you like to play it?  Standard bounce in Black then go our own way West, or something a little fancier that requires a bit more trust?  I'm of course partial to a plan that gets an army rather than a fleet in rum, but other than that pretty open.
messages.input:
My response to RUSSIA:'I mean, who doesn't like a good Juggernaut?  Always a fun start to the game!  

How do you like to play it?  Standard bounce in Black then go our own way West, or something a little fancier that requires a bit more trust?  I'm of course partial to a plan that gets an army rather than a fleet in rum, but other than that pretty open.'.

messages.message: I usually go with the bounce, but due to the unusual nature of this game I would consider other openings. If you would be willing to allow F SEV-BLA I could support us both into a quick takeover of the Balkans. I understand that that move takes a lot of trust, however, so I am of course open to other suggestions.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I usually go with the bounce, but due to the unusual nature of this game I would consider other openings. If you would be willing to allow F SEV-BLA I could support us both into a quick takeover of the Balkans. I understand that that move takes a lot of trust, however, so I am of course open to other suggestions.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's proposal to support a coordinated takeover of the Balkans by allowing the fleet to move from Sevastopol to the Black Sea demonstrates a strategic and cooperative mindset focused on mutually beneficial gains. This proposal aligns with the idea of strong collaboration and trust-building necessary for a successful alliance.

messages.message: Bounce is safer, but rotation is more fun, and it's just a game. Let's do it.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Bounce is safer, but rotation is more fun, and it's just a game. Let's do it.'.

messages.message:
Nice! Have to take some time to think about this tactically but I think we're in a good spot.

 I'm kind of surprised Italy took Trieste, that's statistically a pretty bad move for Italy.
messages.input:
Message from RUSSIA:'Nice! Have to take some time to think about this tactically but I think we're in a good spot.

 I'm kind of surprised Italy took Trieste, that's statistically a pretty bad move for Italy.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's acknowledgement of Italy's decision to take Trieste and the assessment that it may not be a favorable move for Italy shows strategic awareness and a potential alignment with Turkey's interests. This message suggests a shared understanding of the game dynamics and a basis for cooperative decision-making in the alliance.

messages.message:
But a good move for us, unless it's a Key - which it likely isn't, because the moving the second fleet north hurts that opening.

So...umm...  Carry on, I guess.  You're pretty well guaranteed two builds.
messages.input:
My response to RUSSIA:'But a good move for us, unless it's a Key - which it likely isn't, because the moving the second fleet north hurts that opening.

So...umm...  Carry on, I guess.  You're pretty well guaranteed two builds.'.

messages.message: Alrighty then - looks like there will be no coherent defense from the West.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Alrighty then - looks like there will be no coherent defense from the West.'.

messages.message:
Italy getting two builds concerns me a little bit. I want to make sure that you gain two builds if possible in 1902. I'm worried that Italy is going to throw two fleets at you and to be honest losing you would be crippling for my game.

I've been toying with the idea of asking for an Alliance of you, Germany and I to go to 1910 together. I think it's the only thing that makes strategic sense. I can help you with Italy and Germany with England, and all three of us can end up with 10+ centers at the end of 1910.  Do you have any input on this idea?
messages.input:
Message from RUSSIA:'Italy getting two builds concerns me a little bit. I want to make sure that you gain two builds if possible in 1902. I'm worried that Italy is going to throw two fleets at you and to be honest losing you would be crippling for my game.

I've been toying with the idea of asking for an Alliance of you, Germany and I to go to 1910 together. I think it's the only thing that makes strategic sense. I can help you with Italy and Germany with England, and all three of us can end up with 10+ centers at the end of 1910.  Do you have any input on this idea?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's proposal for an alliance between Turkey, Germany, and themselves to progress together until 1910 reflects a strategic vision for collaborative success and mutual benefit. This message indicates a willingness to work closely with Turkey and underlines a shared interest in a stable and successful alliance.

messages.message:
I'm ok with that - and his current issues aside, France is a reasonable alternative to Germany there - especially as I half-expect England/Germany to pull back and react to your three builds.  But I'm good either way.

In any event, yes, I expect Italy to drop two fleets and position on me.  If Austria were actually communicative I'd be trying to spin my positioning as protecting him, but at the moment I'm talking to a wall.  Which is somewhat moot if we move fast enough - he shouldn't really have enough time to firm up a credible defense.
messages.input:
My response to RUSSIA:'I'm ok with that - and his current issues aside, France is a reasonable alternative to Germany there - especially as I half-expect England/Germany to pull back and react to your three builds.  But I'm good either way.

In any event, yes, I expect Italy to drop two fleets and position on me.  If Austria were actually communicative I'd be trying to spin my positioning as protecting him, but at the moment I'm talking to a wall.  Which is somewhat moot if we move fast enough - he shouldn't really have enough time to firm up a credible defense.'.

messages.message: So...interestingly, I was having a conversation with the admin about why I would give an order for my army to be convoyed by your Black Sea fleet even though that wasn't ever something I asked for or discussed.  And it makes me wonder - did you see that move as me sending a message, and if so what message?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'So...interestingly, I was having a conversation with the admin about why I would give an order for my army to be convoyed by your Black Sea fleet even though that wasn't ever something I asked for or discussed.  And it makes me wonder - did you see that move as me sending a message, and if so what message?'.

messages.message: Well, I can tell you that it totally faked out Germany.  They think that I screwed you by not convoying and the Jug isn't even on their radar at the moment. In that aspect it was amazingly successful. Tactically it's not a bad move, keeping an army back offers you a little insurance against an Armenian stab this year (of course I wasn't stabbing anyway, but insurance never hurts). If you had gained two builds it would have left Con and Smy open to build fleets in. Good move.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Well, I can tell you that it totally faked out Germany.  They think that I screwed you by not convoying and the Jug isn't even on their radar at the moment. In that aspect it was amazingly successful. Tactically it's not a bad move, keeping an army back offers you a little insurance against an Armenian stab this year (of course I wasn't stabbing anyway, but insurance never hurts). If you had gained two builds it would have left Con and Smy open to build fleets in. Good move.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's positive assessment of Turkey's move and the strategical success it achieved against Germany reflects a cooperative relationship and a perception of strategic acumen in Turkey's decision-making. This message indicates a level of trust and understanding between Russia and Turkey within their alliance.

messages.message: Germany called it "an obvious bit of Lucy pulling the football away from Charlie Brown"
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Germany called it "an obvious bit of Lucy pulling the football away from Charlie Brown"'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's relay about Germany's perception of the situation as "an obvious bit of Lucy pulling the football away from Charlie Brown" demonstrates an understanding of the strategic deception employed by Turkey and showcases a harmonized viewpoint between the two alliance members. This mutual comprehension enhances the trust and coordination within the alliance.

messages.message: What are you thinking in regards to the Balkans this turn? I've got a possible idea, but I need to kick the tactics around in my head for a minute before I explain it.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'What are you thinking in regards to the Balkans this turn? I've got a possible idea, but I need to kick the tactics around in my head for a minute before I explain it.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's inquiry about the Balkans and the need to deliberate on tactics before formulating a plan reflects a thoughtful and strategic approach to coordinating moves in a crucial region. This message indicates a willingness to collaborate and plan with Turkey for mutual benefit within the alliance's strategic framework.

messages.message:
I think this set of moves is the safe, normal play here:

Russia
A BUD-VIE
A RUM S BUL-SER
F BLA C ANK-BUL
A SEV-UKR

Turkey
A BUL-SER
A ANK-BUL

I think there are other options as well, like if I supported Austria from Serbia to Trieste, allowing you to move into Serbia, keeping Austria at 3 centers and harming Italy. That kind of move has a much greater risk of blowing up in our faces, however.

 I'm willing to follow your lead  here, you tell me which way to jump.
messages.input:
Message from RUSSIA:'I think this set of moves is the safe, normal play here:

Russia
A BUD-VIE
A RUM S BUL-SER
F BLA C ANK-BUL
A SEV-UKR

Turkey
A BUL-SER
A ANK-BUL

I think there are other options as well, like if I supported Austria from Serbia to Trieste, allowing you to move into Serbia, keeping Austria at 3 centers and harming Italy. That kind of move has a much greater risk of blowing up in our faces, however.

 I'm willing to follow your lead  here, you tell me which way to jump.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's proposed set of moves and the consideration of alternative options for tactical plays demonstrate a collaborative and flexible approach in coordinating with Turkey. This message reflects an open dialogue and a willingness to discuss strategic decisions within the alliance, enhancing the trust and joint decision-making process.

messages.message:
Well hello, lots of messages to catch up on.  So the convoy move had more or less the intended effect. 😀

I *finally* am getting responses from Austria, so trying to stand Italy out of Ionian in the sitting is an option. Otherwise it's fall back on original plan which is basically the moves you have up above. Trying to get tricksy with supporting Austria forward sounds like a way to end up with hostile units in Galicia.   If I were going to put forth another option, it would probably be for you to rotate rum to gal while I tap Greece and Serbia - letting Budapest choose which move to support.
messages.input:
My response to RUSSIA:'Well hello, lots of messages to catch up on.  So the convoy move had more or less the intended effect. 😀

I *finally* am getting responses from Austria, so trying to stand Italy out of Ionian in the sitting is an option. Otherwise it's fall back on original plan which is basically the moves you have up above. Trying to get tricksy with supporting Austria forward sounds like a way to end up with hostile units in Galicia.   If I were going to put forth another option, it would probably be for you to rotate rum to gal while I tap Greece and Serbia - letting Budapest choose which move to support.'.

messages.message: Well, not perfect, but we can work with this. Serbia will take your proxy order this turn - I assume supporting rum to bud?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Well, not perfect, but we can work with this. Serbia will take your proxy order this turn - I assume supporting rum to bud?'.

messages.message: Alternative proposal: use rum to support Serbia, and punch your fleet through Constantinople to get it on the front line.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Alternative proposal: use rum to support Serbia, and punch your fleet through Constantinople to get it on the front line.'.

messages.message: Deadline's looming. What's the plan, chief?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Deadline's looming. What's the plan, chief?'.

messages.message: I've been informed that Germany and England will be moving against me this turn, unfortunately. I'm going to move RUM-BUD, all other moves will be heading North.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I've been informed that Germany and England will be moving against me this turn, unfortunately. I'm going to move RUM-BUD, all other moves will be heading North.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's communication about the planned moves and the acknowledgment of the potential threat from Germany and England indicates transparency and a readiness to work together strategically with Turkey. This message underscores the need for cooperation in navigating challenging circumstances and suggests a collaborative approach within the alliance.

messages.message: Fair. Didn't sound like they had gotten their shit together, but do what you need. Serbia will support
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Fair. Didn't sound like they had gotten their shit together, but do what you need. Serbia will support'.

messages.message: Do you need anything specific besides me just pushing along in the South?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Do you need anything specific besides me just pushing along in the South?'.

messages.message: Could you tap TRI? I may be able to snag VIE this year, depending on what Germany decides to do.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Could you tap TRI? I may be able to snag VIE this year, depending on what Germany decides to do.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's request for Turkey to tap Trieste to potentially secure Vienna aligns with the strategic goal of expanding territories in the East. This message indicates clear communication and a collaborative approach within the alliance to coordinate moves for mutual benefit.

messages.message: Done. Let me know if not needed, as if be better off trying to rotate.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Done. Let me know if not needed, as if be better off trying to rotate.'.

messages.message: Side note: for a bunch of Diplomacy players, this board isn't very talkative.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Side note: for a bunch of Diplomacy players, this board isn't very talkative.'.

messages.message: I'll agree with that. You and Germany are the only ones seemingly willing to communicate with me, and Germany has been talked into a bad faith deal with England it appears. I'm trying to use England's NMR to drive a wedge in that relationship now.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I'll agree with that. You and Germany are the only ones seemingly willing to communicate with me, and Germany has been talked into a bad faith deal with England it appears. I'm trying to use England's NMR to drive a wedge in that relationship now.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's observation about the lack of communication on the board and the strategic approach to capitalize on England's potential NMR to create discord in their relationship with Germany demonstrates a shrewd diplomatic strategy and a desire to exploit opportunities for advantage within the game. This message reflects a keen awareness of the dynamics and a proactive mindset in navigating alliances and rivalries.

messages.message:
I think the way we played 1901 made Germany think that I am a giant threat, when in actuality I really do want to work with Germany. 

Do you think we can get you in Trieste this year?
messages.input:
Message from RUSSIA:'I think the way we played 1901 made Germany think that I am a giant threat, when in actuality I really do want to work with Germany. 

Do you think we can get you in Trieste this year?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's expression of the desire to work with Germany and the strategic goal of securing Trieste for Turkey indicates a cooperative attitude and a shared interest in fostering positive relationships within the alliance. This message highlights a collaborative approach and a willingness to prioritize Turkey's growth and success in the game.

messages.message: Quite possibly. You'll want me to tap it anyway to help protect Vienna.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Quite possibly. You'll want me to tap it anyway to help protect Vienna.'.

messages.message: Found the negotiation point with Germany - he wants Trieste. Is that something you're willing to bargain on, and if so what do you want?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Found the negotiation point with Germany - he wants Trieste. Is that something you're willing to bargain on, and if so what do you want?'.

messages.message: (to be clear, I'm ordered to Trieste myself until I hear otherwise from you)
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'(to be clear, I'm ordered to Trieste myself until I hear otherwise from you)'.

messages.message: I think I have something worked out that takes some of the issue off of you. You'll know it worked if you see some chairs in the West this turn. 😀
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'I think I have something worked out that takes some of the issue off of you. You'll know it worked if you see some chairs in the West this turn. 😀'.

messages.message: Wow, autocorrect. Some of the pressure off of you. Chaos in the West.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Wow, autocorrect. Some of the pressure off of you. Chaos in the West.'.

messages.message: That's awesome, I can work with that. It gives me the ability to make offensive moves in the North again with Germany under pressure.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'That's awesome, I can work with that. It gives me the ability to make offensive moves in the North again with Germany under pressure.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Russia's positive response to the planned strategy by Turkey showcasing efforts to alleviate pressure and create opportunities in the West suggests a collaborative approach within the alliance. This message indicates a shared understanding and readiness to capitalize on the situation for mutual gains.
